item.title: Only One Person Who Can Save The 12-Year-Old Girl With Aplastic Anemia. Is It You? - Patient Worthy
item.description:
Only One Person Who Can Save The 12-Year-Old Girl With Aplastic Anemia. Is It You? - Patient Worthy

Alex Pasichnyk is a 12-year-old girl from Canada, who enjoys playing piano and swimming. Last June, her life was suddenly interrupted by a rare disease. Alex has to leave her life in the sixth grade-- she's only been to school three times since everything changed.

item.title: Rally for marrow match - St. Albert Gazette
item.description:
Rally for marrow match - St. Albert Gazette

Registering to be a bone marrow donor is the easiest thing in the world. Just show up, get the inside of your cheek swabbed, and that's it. The family of Alex Pasichnyk is hoping that there's a long line of people for a bone marrow drive next Saturday at Servus Place.

item.title: Stem-cell match sought for girl, 11
item.description:
Stem-cell match sought for girl, 11

A Central Saanich woman is calling for donors, especially those of Ukrainian, Polish and English ancestry, to find a stem-cell match for her grandniece, who is suffering from a fatal blood disease. "When they are looking for a bone-marrow donor, ethnicity evidently plays a big part in finding a match," said Cheryl Taschuk.

item.title: Alex Pasichnyk Bone Marrow Donor Drive - Polonia Edmonton News
item.description:
Alex Pasichnyk Bone Marrow Donor Drive - Polonia Edmonton News

Alex Pasichnyk is a 12-year-old girl who loves art, animals, swimming and is now in for the fight of her life. Everyone who knows Alex is devastated by this sudden turn of events, especially her parents (Lisa and Sheldon) and her sister (Kimber). She is a St.

item.title: 12-year-old St. Albert girl needs urgent bone marrow transplant
item.description:
12-year-old St. Albert girl needs urgent bone marrow transplant

Lying in a hospital bed two days a week is not something 12-year-old Alex Pasichnyk is thrilled about. But since the end of June she's been going to the Stollery Children's Hospital every Tuesday and Friday for blood transfusions after she was diagnosed with a rare blood disease called severe aplastic anemia.
